boat.construction_details: Carvel pitch pine on grown oak frames
boat.full_description:
There are no records as yet of Venture's builder or build date.There are records of 4 Ventures registered as trawl boats/nobbys, but none have the same dimensions as Venture 220. Close examination of her photos and comparison with photos of nobbys including Lassie of Chester suggest that she was built by John Crossfield at Conway. She has the same narrow sheer plank and rubbing strake (moulding) as his fishing nobbys.  Her high topsides for a fishing nobby, widish cockpit and narrowish side decks (normally each 1/3 of the beam on a fishing nobby), iron guard rail stanchions and cross trees in 1974 suggest that she was originally a yacht.

Venture was salvaged in 1965 by Dennis Crompton of Warrington, who gave her a major overhaul. He sold her to Jay Cresswell (OGA member) in 1974, who re-registered her for commercial fishing on the Beaumaris register (BS 120).  

Sold south in 1977 after three successful years of work, mostly in Scottish waters. New owner was Sam Bayliss (also OGA member). He attempted to buy her back in the early 1980s through a proxy but failed. She had a major refit by Richard Coles (also OGA member) starting in 1984, including plank and a new engine installation. Richard and his daughter took her to the 1996 Brest IFOS.

Her photo gallery includes an image of her wearing a sail with the Fishing Registry CO88. Nobby CO88 was bought during the war by a company taking advantage of subsidies paid to the fishing industry. She was abandoned at the end of the war in the Manchester Ship Canal. Venture recycled her sail even though CO88 was a larger boat at 36' x 10'6" x 6'.  It was used as the pattern for a new main, which was ordered from Fleetwood Trawler Supply Co. which still had a loft at that time. It was a powerful yet manageable sail and enabled Venture to tow a beam trawl comfortably during her spell fishing as BS120.

The foresail had been made many years earlier, again for another nobby, but was like new. The jib was made by Leitch of Tarbert using an earlier sail as the pattern.
boat.name: Venture
boat.short_description: She was originally a fishing Nobby in North west England.
